div1.p: Carter writes about Laura Armistead Carter's sickness and gives her a detailed prescription. He also describes his flower gardens.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Laura Armistead Carter, August 15, 1911
div1.opener:
The Kerrs nice but stiff live in the same house (Marine Hosp'l
with Anderson. I wrote him not them
Louisville Ky
Aug 15 11
Dear Laura:
div1.p:
I write by this mail to the clerk
at J.H. Hospital to find if Thayer is
in Baltimore & if not. I think it improb-
able that he is when he will proba-
bly resume his service there. You go
on about your business unless you be-
come so that you think it is advisable to act at
in go in hospital without delay, & you I
will make all arrangements neces-
sary, in case it seems best for you
to go enter hospital. I wish you could
have had-say-2 months longer inter-
val between your school & your trip
so that you could have gone to bed here on careful
make up the requisite messages from me to Norfolk & Portsmouth
friends pafer is lacking not such minds

careful, generous diet & seen what the
out come would have been. However
if, as seems not improbable, you enter hos'l
before you return I will go on &
go with you. You can get well not
only better, & it is well worth while
that you do so. Whether medical treatment
will be sufficient. I think so - or not
we can well leave to your physician.
But in any case you ought to be well,
Ed. had an attack yesterday like
the one he had when miss Marris
was here & had to leave school & will is not
3
isbe able to go today
still he had this
disability. I satis-
fied myself of
that, & was not
humbugging
I think he is on the
verge of getting
through. This will
interfere with it
of course. He reads
to me every even-
ing & reads I think
well, at any rate
he reads every evening evening

PUBLIC HEALTH AND MARINE-HOSPITAL SERVICE,
OFFICE OF MEDICAL OFFICER IN COMMAND.
Surgeon.
SUBJECT:
No. of Inclosures,
Hope Helen will not North River, but fear she will

I am under the weather since Saturday
morning, not sick, but with a surgical
trouble, which I brought from Panama. It got
worse suddenly & I had a small operation done
Saturday morning-Cocoäine-& am pretty
well out of the woods now. Made sick call
this morning. But I will not be entirely
to my selffor-say-for 7 or 10 days. It is a
nuisance about not being able to attend
to my flowers. I mind that most. The Roses
ought to have stopped blooming-but they
have not. I got about 40 this morning
& same beautiful ones are Lyons & a num-
ber of Pres. Carnot 's, Killarney's & Detroits.
The Gladioli too are the best of any
I have ever seen: simply wonderful,
about 3 4 fold handsome than last year.

Some purble-a rich blue purple-& thence
shades of lavinder Cream. White
& Red & every blend & mixture conceiv-
able & all the same soft, vivid colors that
we had last year & much larger.

Oh. I will send you the Geographic Mag-
azine. Containing Dora Kean's Alpine
climbing, Photographs excellent. Also
get a copy of the American Magazine
for July (I think that is it) for an account
of Miss Winifred Sackoille Stand. I
have not read it, but if 1/2 what the ex-
critic is Military Surgeons say- she is
a “WONDER.” all capitals:

my trouble last
prevented me
eating any grapes
Concads- which
are ripe

Did the service
people act white?
Most of them like
me & I feel sure
that same of them
called but who
whether was in town
& whose wife was in
town I did not know

PUBLIC HEALTH AND MARINE-HOSPITAL SERVICE,
OFFICE OF MEDICAL OFFICER IN COMMAND.
Surgeon.
SUBJECT:
No. of Inclosures,

Form 1765.
H.R. Carter
TREASURY DEPARTMENT.
Aug 3 5/11
Dear L.

I enclose your Rxs. The mixing the Sodu
Bicarb & the chloroform as you do it can-
not possibly have any effect

The cii acid mixt. is only 2/3 as strong
as the one you had-as I recollect it. Of
the other, as I recollect, you took a full tea-
spoonful only in emergencies-which was
15 drops a teaspoonful of this is 10 drops.
Regulate your-dose then by what you
need 20 drops is not an excessive dose
& the acid can do no harm except to your
teeth: Note that a tea spoonful is 4 cub-
ic 4. Cubic centimeters-in this bottle
not 5 as in the last as I wrote this Rx in a-
English measures: Hence 5 C.C. of it is
10+10/4 = 12½ drops: Regulate your dose to 50 as
to get about 10. to if needed 15 drops or 20
at a dose.

I would take As long as you have acid stomach
or fermentation of (apparently) bacterial or yeast
(or yeasty)origin in the morning before breakfast I would take the spirits of
chloroform in doses of 20 to 30 drops & re-
peat, if necessary to 2 or even 4 doses: not
using too much water for this. That is you don't
want to dilute it any more than enough to
not burn your mouth or throat. It is a good
germicide & a slight stimulant. My recollection is
that 12 drops of it contains 1 minim of chloroform
so 36 would be only 3 minim = 3 water drops in size.
I find see Dispensatory it is 6% chloroform. So 30 drops
contains 1.8 1 8/10 drops = 9/10 of a minim chloroform. You can
take 4 2 to 3. C. Centimeters without any damage
If the morning fermentation or an empty stomach
Form 1765.
TREASURY DEPARTMENT.

doesn't stop get a little fine carbolic acid
half an ounce or one drachum is enough, & take
about 3 to 5 drops in about 10 C.C. of water instead of
the chloroform. I would give much if you were
entirely well. Yet I am reasonably sure that
you can be made so

I think Ned is telling the truth
am sorry you won't see the Whitings & am
sorry Mrs. Leys could not have you. Too
crowded I judge.

I wrote yesterday, to Kinyoun: Anderson & White
that you would be in Washington. Am not sure
White is there & am afraid that the wives
of the others may be out of towns also wrote to
Glennan-telling him. I was entirely willing to
go to H. or - anywhere else the Bureau thought neces-
sary but whether I “wished for this detail” getting
his letter deform I could not say until I know
more about it. Then gave him some
general advice. I am in no way 1-
verse to remaining here. I would have
one more year of flowers & then I could
forego them for a long while. It is like
having ones “fling”.

You will be in Portsmouth before Tumb-
sey returns I fear as I presume you will not
stay long in Washington. You ought to tell
Ethel that you know Straub & if she told
him you were there it would be all right.
He is rather a big man-he in his corps now
The representative of the Med. corps as the
general staff. He is an able man too.
Although he & Dr. Gorgas never got along.
Hasta la Vista carissima. Don't take up your
time with long letters & sent a letter or postal to
Miss Fox who Ned says is mad because Mrs. M. has heard
from you & not she herself.
